Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how language, facial expressions and gestures are used to interact with others when asking for and providing information, making offers, exclaiming, requesting and giving commands
Elaboration: Recognising the effects of words, signing, gestures and body language on the way that communications are received by others

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how language, facial expressions and gestures are used to interact with others when asking for and providing information, making offers, exclaiming, requesting and giving commands
Elaboration: Understanding that symbols, gestures and body language are key components of communication in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how language, facial expressions and gestures are used to interact with others when asking for and providing information, making offers, exclaiming, requesting and giving commands
Elaboration: Viewing short films and discussing how characters use words and body language to convey emotions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how language, facial expressions and gestures are used to interact with others when asking for and providing information, making offers, exclaiming, requesting and giving commands
Elaboration: Learning the difference between closed questions (for example, ‘Are you ready?’) and open questions (for example, ‘What made this text so exciting?’)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore language to provide reasons for likes, dislikes and preferences
Elaboration: Using words such as ‘because’ to introduce reasons for likes, dislikes and preferences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore language to provide reasons for likes, dislikes and preferences
Elaboration: Exploring comparative words (adjectives) to express the degree of preference, for example ‘better’ and ‘faster’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how types of texts are organised according to their purpose, such as to recount, narrate, express opinion, inform, report and explain
Elaboration: Discussing and comparing the purposes and organisation of familiar texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how types of texts are organised according to their purpose, such as to recount, narrate, express opinion, inform, report and explain
Elaboration: Becoming familiar with the typical stages of types of texts, for example recount and procedure

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how types of texts are organised according to their purpose, such as to recount, narrate, express opinion, inform, report and explain
Elaboration: Recognising that the structure of a text may include words and pictures; for example, an informative text may include words, illustrations and diagrams

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how repetition, rhyme and rhythm create cohesion in simple poems, chants and songs
Elaboration: Identifying patterns of repetition in texts, for example repetition of sentence patterns such as ‘Have you seen …’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how repetition, rhyme and rhythm create cohesion in simple poems, chants and songs
Elaboration: Discussing different poems and identifying rhyme, for example end-of-line rhyme

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how concepts about print in printed and digital texts are organised using features such as page numbers, tables of contents, headings and titles, navigation buttons, swipe screens, verbal commands, links and images
Elaboration: Comparing the layout of printed and digital texts, for example the layout of print and images in an information book and the layout of information in an online text

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that a simple sentence consists of a single independent clause representing a single event or idea
Elaboration: Knowing that a single event or idea can include a process, a happening or a state (verb), the participant or who or what is involved (noun group/phrase), and the surrounding circumstances (adverb group/phrase), for example ‘Teddy (the participant: who or what is involved) reads (a process, a happening or a state) the book (surrounding circumstances).’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that a simple sentence consists of a single independent clause representing a single event or idea
Elaboration: Understanding that simple sentences answer questions such as ‘What is happening?’ and ‘Who or what is involved?’ along with details such as ‘Where?’, ‘When?’ and ‘How?’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that words can represent people, places and things (nouns, including pronouns), happenings and states (verbs), qualities (adjectives), relationships in time and space (prepositions) and details such as when, where and how (adverbs)
Elaboration: Understanding that words or groups of words can represent the participants (nouns; for example people, places or things) that are involved in various activities or processes (verbs of doing, saying, thinking and being) and the details or circumstances surrounding the activity (adjectives and adverbs that answer ‘When?’, ‘Where?’ and ‘How?’)

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that words can represent people, places and things (nouns, including pronouns), happenings and states (verbs), qualities (adjectives), relationships in time and space (prepositions) and details such as when, where and how (adverbs)
Elaboration: Recognising how a sentence can be made more specific by adding adjectives, adverbs and precise verbs

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Compare how images and sound in different types of texts contribute to meaning
Elaboration: Comparing images from texts where images of the same subject are represented differently, for example a cartoon image of an animal, a photograph of an animal, a painting of an animal and a digital image of an animal in an advertisement

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Compare how images and sound in different types of texts contribute to meaning
Elaboration: Understanding how authors and illustrators build up meaning across a sequence of images

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Compare how images and sound in different types of texts contribute to meaning
Elaboration: Understanding that some images convey meaning that is not included in the accompanying written text; for example, a diagram shows information about how parts of a plant are connected, which is not explained in the written text

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise and understand vocabulary across the curriculum, such as topic-specific vocabulary in other learning areas
Elaboration: Using appropriate topic-specific vocabulary when discussing a learning area topic

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise and understand vocabulary across the curriculum, such as topic-specific vocabulary in other learning areas
Elaboration: Using appropriate vocabulary for an Acknowledgement of Country at assemblies and other school events using protocols to recognise the Traditional Owners of Country

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise and understand vocabulary across the curriculum, such as topic-specific vocabulary in other learning areas
Elaboration: Identifying words for topics studied at school, for example vocabulary used for weather and seasons

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that written language uses punctuation such as full stops, question marks and exclamation marks, and uses capital letters for proper nouns
Elaboration: Using intonation and pauses in response to punctuation, when reading

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that written language uses punctuation such as full stops, question marks and exclamation marks, and uses capital letters for proper nouns
Elaboration: Identifying different sentence boundary punctuation, when reading

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that written language uses punctuation such as full stops, question marks and exclamation marks, and uses capital letters for proper nouns
Elaboration: Writing different types of sentences (for example, statements and questions) and discussing appropriate punctuation

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that written language uses punctuation such as full stops, question marks and exclamation marks, and uses capital letters for proper nouns
Elaboration: Identifying and using capital letters to name places and cultural festivals and holidays

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how language and images are used to create characters, settings and events in literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a wide range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Discussing how animal characters reflect human characteristics, for example discussing the creation of animal characters and their human qualities in fables by a wide range of world authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how language and images are used to create characters, settings and events in literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a wide range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Discussing how characters, settings and events are described or depicted in literature by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how language and images are used to create characters, settings and events in literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a wide range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Discussing the events associated with Australian animal characters and what is learnt about their characters in picture books from a wide range of Australian authors

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss a range of literary texts and share responses by making connections with their own experiences
Elaboration: Generating questions about characters, settings and events from books and sharing responses

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss a range of literary texts and share responses by making connections with their own experiences
Elaboration: Discussing a range of texts and offering opinions about how they reflect their own experiences

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss a range of literary texts and share responses by making connections with their own experiences
Elaboration: Expressing responses to characters and events in stories using drawing and role-play

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss a range of literary texts and share responses by making connections with their own experiences
Elaboration: Identifying who is telling the story in a range of texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss plots, characters and settings through a range of literary texts
Elaboration: Recognising similar characters and settings in a range of literary texts, for example traditional tales, narrative poems and fables

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss plots, characters and settings through a range of literary texts
Elaboration: Discussing whether features of settings, including time (year, season) and place (country or city), are realistic or imagined

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss plots, characters and settings through a range of literary texts
Elaboration: Discussing how plots develop, including beginnings (orientation), how the problem (complication) is introduced and how it is solved (resolution)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Listen to, recite and discuss poems, chants, rhymes and songs, and imitate and invent sound patterns including alliteration and rhyme
Elaboration: Listening to performance poetry, chants or songs from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Listen to, recite and discuss poems, chants, rhymes and songs, and imitate and invent sound patterns including alliteration and rhyme
Elaboration: Exploring poetry, chants and songs from Asian cultures

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Listen to, recite and discuss poems, chants, rhymes and songs, and imitate and invent sound patterns including alliteration and rhyme
Elaboration: Listening to haiku poems about familiar topics such as nature and the seasons

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Retell or adapt a range of previously encountered literary texts using plot and characters, structure, language features and vocabulary, through role-play, writing and drawing
Elaboration: Writing or sharing character descriptions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Retell or adapt a range of previously encountered literary texts using plot and characters, structure, language features and vocabulary, through role-play, writing and drawing
Elaboration: Imitating a characteristic piece of speech or dialogue, or the attitudes or expressions of favourite characters in texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Retell or adapt a range of previously encountered literary texts using plot and characters, structure, language features and vocabulary, through role-play, writing and drawing
Elaboration: Retelling key events in stories using oral language, visual arts, digital tools or performance

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills including turn-taking, speaking clearly, using active listening behaviours and responding to the read or spoken contributions of others, and contributing ideas and questions
Elaboration: Using turn-taking in group and pair work

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills including turn-taking, speaking clearly, using active listening behaviours and responding to the read or spoken contributions of others, and contributing ideas and questions
Elaboration: Building a conversation by staying on topic, supporting other speakers, eliciting responses, listening supportively and attentively, asking relevant questions, providing useful feedback and prompting

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills including turn-taking, speaking clearly, using active listening behaviours and responding to the read or spoken contributions of others, and contributing ideas and questions
Elaboration: Participating in informal and structured class, group and pair discussions about content area topics, ideas and information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills including turn-taking, speaking clearly, using active listening behaviours and responding to the read or spoken contributions of others, and contributing ideas and questions
Elaboration: Interacting appropriately with peers, teachers and visitors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills including turn-taking, speaking clearly, using active listening behaviours and responding to the read or spoken contributions of others, and contributing ideas and questions
Elaboration: Formulating different types of questions to ask a speaker or someone reading aloud, such as open and closed questions and ‘when’, ‘why’ and ‘how’ questions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver short spoken texts to an audience using features of voice
Elaboration: Reporting the results of group activities

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver short spoken texts to an audience using features of voice
Elaboration: Explaining how to do or make something

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver short spoken texts to an audience using features of voice
Elaboration: Giving short oral presentations about areas of interest or content area topics, speaking clearly and with appropriate volume, and using content-specific vocabulary

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver short spoken texts to an audience using features of voice
Elaboration: Experimenting with volume and pace for particular purposes; for example, presenting information, retelling stories and reciting rhymes and poems

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver short spoken texts to an audience using features of voice
Elaboration: Giving reasons why the class should learn a particular game

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Blend, segment and manipulate phonemes in words (phonemic awareness), including words with consonant blends at the beginning and end, and words with more than one syllable
Elaboration: Making sounds in order to say a given spoken word, for example ‘s-p-oo-n’ and ‘f-i-s-t’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Blend, segment and manipulate phonemes in words (phonemic awareness), including words with consonant blends at the beginning and end, and words with more than one syllable
Elaboration: Manipulating phonemes in spoken words by addition, deletion and substitution of initial, medial and final phonemes to generate new words (phonological awareness)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Blend, segment and manipulate phonemes in words (phonemic awareness), including words with consonant blends at the beginning and end, and words with more than one syllable
Elaboration: Adding, substituting or deleting phonemes in any position in one-syllable words with up to 4 phonemes

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Blend, segment and manipulate phonemes in words (phonemic awareness), including words with consonant blends at the beginning and end, and words with more than one syllable
Elaboration: Substituting medial sounds in spoken words to make new words, for example ‘pin’, ‘pen’, ‘pan’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Blend, segment and manipulate phonemes in words (phonemic awareness), including words with consonant blends at the beginning and end, and words with more than one syllable
Elaboration: Substituting final sounds in spoken words; for example, substituting the ‘t’ in ‘pet’ with ‘g’ to form a new word, ‘peg’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of short vowels, common long vowels, consonant blends and digraphs to read and write one- and 2-syllable words
Elaboration: Using knowledge of letters and sounds to write words with short vowels (for example, ‘man’) and with common long vowel sounds (for example, ‘time’)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of short vowels, common long vowels, consonant blends and digraphs to read and write one- and 2-syllable words
Elaboration: Using knowledge of letter sounds to write one-syllable words with consonant digraphs and consonant blends, for example ‘wish’ and ‘rest’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that a letter can represent more than one sound and that a syllable must contain a vowel sound
Elaboration: Recognising that letters can have more than one sound, for example the letter ‘u’ in ‘cut’, ‘put’ and ‘use’ and the letter ‘a’ in ‘cat’, ‘father’ and ‘any’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that a letter can represent more than one sound and that a syllable must contain a vowel sound
Elaboration: Recognising sounds that can be produced by different letters, for example the ‘s’ sound in ‘sat’ and ‘cent’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Spell one- and 2-syllable words with common letter patterns
Elaboration: Writing one- and 2-syllable words containing known blends, for example ‘bl’ and ‘st’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read and write an increasing number of high-frequency words
Elaboration: Learning an increasing number of high-frequency words and reading them independently, for example ‘one’, ‘have’ and ‘pretty’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and know how to use grammatical morphemes to create word families
Elaboration: Building word families from common morphemes, for example ‘play’, ‘plays’, ‘playing’, ‘played’ and ‘playground’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and know how to use grammatical morphemes to create word families
Elaboration: Using morphemes to read words; for example, by recognising the base word in words such as ‘walk-ed’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read decodable and authentic texts using developing phonic knowledge, phrasing and fluency, and make and monitor meaning using context and grammatical knowledge
Elaboration: Recognising most high-frequency words when reading a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read decodable and authentic texts using developing phonic knowledge, phrasing and fluency, and make and monitor meaning using context and grammatical knowledge
Elaboration: Self-correcting or asking for assistance when meaning breaks down

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss different types of texts drawn from a range of cultures and experiences
Elaboration: Discussing different types of texts encountered in school and in the community, and identifying their purposes

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss different types of texts drawn from a range of cultures and experiences
Elaboration: Recognising that types of texts with similar purposes usually have predictable structures

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe some similarities and differences between narrative, informative and persuasive texts
Elaboration: Comparing and discussing different types of texts, identifying some features that distinguish those that ‘tell stories’ from those that ‘give opinions’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe some similarities and differences between narrative, informative and persuasive texts
Elaboration: Selecting text types for a particular purpose or task, for example a website that will give information about a learning area topic, or a book that will tell a story about an animal

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning, and draw on learnt vocabulary and growing knowledge of context and text structures to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Identifying information and details from spoken informative texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning, and draw on learnt vocabulary and growing knowledge of context and text structures to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Building topic knowledge and learning new vocabulary before and during reading

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning, and draw on learnt vocabulary and growing knowledge of context and text structures to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Making predictions from the cover, from illustrations and at points in the text before reading on, and confirming and adjusting understanding after reading

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning, and draw on learnt vocabulary and growing knowledge of context and text structures to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Drawing inferences and explaining inferences using clues from the text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning, and draw on learnt vocabulary and growing knowledge of context and text structures to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Making connections with existing knowledge and personal experiences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create short narrative and informative texts, written and spoken, on personal and learnt topics, including using some topic-specific vocabulary, appropriate multimodal elements, and a structure with an opening, middle and conclusion
Elaboration: Applying emerging knowledge of text structure and grammar when creating text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create short narrative and informative texts, written and spoken, on personal and learnt topics, including using some topic-specific vocabulary, appropriate multimodal elements, and a structure with an opening, middle and conclusion
Elaboration: Using learning area vocabulary when creating text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create short narrative and informative texts, written and spoken, on personal and learnt topics, including using some topic-specific vocabulary, appropriate multimodal elements, and a structure with an opening, middle and conclusion
Elaboration: Creating digital images and composing a story or information sequence on-screen using images and captions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Re-read their own texts and discuss possible changes to improve meaning, spelling and punctuation
Elaboration: Adding or deleting words on a page or screen to improve meaning; for example, adding an adjective to add meaning to a noun

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Re-read their own texts and discuss possible changes to improve meaning, spelling and punctuation
Elaboration: Beginning to use dictionaries and resources to check and correct spelling

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Re-read their own texts and discuss possible changes to improve meaning, spelling and punctuation
Elaboration: Identifying words that might not be spelt correctly

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Write words using unjoined lower-case and upper-case letters
Elaboration: Continuing to develop a functional pencil grip/grasp
